title: How to Make Dal Fry

steps.headline: Soak the dal for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Measure ½ cup (100 g) of split pigeon peas (toovar dal), ¼ cup (50 g) of split Bengal gram (chana dal), and ¼ cup (50 g) of split skinless green gram (dhuli moong dal) into a bowl. Pour enough water to cover the dal and let them soak for 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Place water, seasonings, and soaked dal in the pressure cooker.
steps.description: Pour 2 1/2 cups (590 ml) of water into your pressure cooker. Drain the soaked dal and place the dal in the pressure cooker along with ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of asafoetida (hing) and ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of turmeric powder. Stir the mixture until it's combined.

steps.headline: Seal the lid and pressure cook the dal.
steps.description: Put the lid on the pressure cooker and seal it completely. Put the pressure cooker on the stove and turn the heat to high. Cook the dal until 4 to 5 whistles of steam released. This should take about 10 minutes. Turn off the heat and set the dal aside. If you don't have a pressure cooker, you could place the seasonings, water, and soaked dal in a large pot. Cook the dal over medium-high heat until the mixture is completely soft and cooked. This can take 25 to 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Toast the cumin seeds in butter for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Place 1 1/2 tablespoons (21 g) of the butter into a large pot. Melt the butter over medium heat and stir in 1 teaspoon (2 g) of cumin seeds. Stir and cook the cumin seeds until you begin to smell them. This should take about 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Mince the fresh ginger and garlic.
steps.description: Peel a few cloves of fresh garlic and a 1-inch (2.5-cm) piece of fresh ginger. Use a sharp knife to mince the ginger and garlic. Mince enough garlic to measure 1 tablespoon (8 g).

steps.headline: Sauté the garlic and ginger for 1 minute.
steps.description: Stir the minced garlic and ginger into the pot with the cumin seeds. Stir and sauté these aromatics for 1 minute.

steps.headline: Chop the green chilies, onion, and tomato.
steps.description: Peel 1 medium onion. Wash 2 green chilies and 1 medium tomato. Finely chop the vegetables into very small pieces. Set the diced tomato aside.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion and green chilies for 5 to 7 minutes.
steps.description: Add the diced onion and green chilies to the pot. Stir and sauté the vegetables over medium heat until the onion begins to caramelize a little. This should take 5 to 7 minutes.

steps.headline: Stir in the diced tomato and salt.
steps.description: Add the diced tomato and stir in salt according to your taste. Sauté the spice mixture until the tomato softens a little and releases its juice.

steps.headline: Stir in the remaining seasonings.
steps.description: Measure 1 teaspoon (3 g) of red chili powder, ½ teaspoon (1.5 g) of garam masala powder, and 1 tablespoon (4 g) of chopped cilantro into the pot. Stir the spice mixture and turn off the heat.

steps.headline: Stir the cooked dal into the spice mixture.
steps.description: Release the pressure from the pressure cooker and remove the lid. Scoop the cooked dal into the pot with the spice mixture. Stir well to combine the mixtures.

steps.headline: Fry the dal for for 4 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the heat on to medium-high and cook the dal fry until it thickens and bubbles. This should take 4 to 5 minutes. Stir the dal fry occasionally to keep it from sticking to the pot.

steps.headline: Stir in the butter and lemon juice.
steps.description: Turn off the heat and stir in the remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons (21 g) of butter until it melts. Squeeze half of a lemon and stir in the juice until it's incorporated.

steps.headline: Serve the dal fry.
steps.description: Sprinkle a little chopped fresh cilantro over the dal fry and serve it while it's thick and hot. Consider serving the dal fry with steamed rice, chapati, naan, or raita. Store the leftover dal fry in an airtight container in the refrigerator. You can keep the dal fry for 2 to 3 days.

text: Preparing the Trevati Dal Soak the dal for 30 minutes. Measure ½ cup (100 g) of split pigeon peas (toovar dal), ¼ cup (50 g) of split Bengal gram (chana dal), and ¼ cup (50 g) of split skinless green gram (dhuli moong dal) into a bowl. Pour enough water to cover the dal and let them soak for 30 minutes. Place water, seasonings, and soaked dal in the pressure cooker. Pour 2 1/2 cups (590 ml) of water into your pressure cooker. Drain the soaked dal and place the dal in the pressure cooker along with ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of asafoetida (hing) and ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of turmeric powder. Stir the mixture until it's combined. Seal the lid and pressure cook the dal. Put the lid on the pressure cooker and seal it completely. Put the pressure cooker on the stove and turn the heat to high. Cook the dal until 4 to 5 whistles of steam released. This should take about 10 minutes. Turn off the heat and set the dal aside. If you don't have a pressure cooker, you could place the seasonings, water, and soaked dal in a large pot. Cook the dal over medium-high heat until the mixture is completely soft and cooked. This can take 25 to 30 minutes. Tempering the Spices Toast the cumin seeds in butter for 30 seconds. Place 1 1/2 tablespoons (21 g) of the butter into a large pot. Melt the butter over medium heat and stir in 1 teaspoon (2 g) of cumin seeds. Stir and cook the cumin seeds until you begin to smell them. This should take about 30 seconds. Mince the fresh ginger and garlic. Peel a few cloves of fresh garlic and a 1-inch (2.5-cm) piece of fresh ginger. Use a sharp knife to mince the ginger and garlic. Mince enough garlic to measure 1 tablespoon (8 g). Sauté the garlic and ginger for 1 minute. Stir the minced garlic and ginger into the pot with the cumin seeds. Stir and sauté these aromatics for 1 minute. Chop the green chilies, onion, and tomato. Peel 1 medium onion. Wash 2 green chilies and 1 medium tomato. Finely chop the vegetables into very small pieces. Set the diced tomato aside. Sauté the onion and green chilies for 5 to 7 minutes. Add the diced onion and green chilies to the pot. Stir and sauté the vegetables over medium heat until the onion begins to caramelize a little. This should take 5 to 7 minutes. Stir in the diced tomato and salt. Add the diced tomato and stir in salt according to your taste. Sauté the spice mixture until the tomato softens a little and releases its juice. Stir in the remaining seasonings. Measure 1 teaspoon (3 g) of red chili powder, ½ teaspoon (1.5 g) of garam masala powder, and 1 tablespoon (4 g) of chopped cilantro into the pot. Stir the spice mixture and turn off the heat. Assembling the Dal Fry Stir the cooked dal into the spice mixture. Release the pressure from the pressure cooker and remove the lid. Scoop the cooked dal into the pot with the spice mixture. Stir well to combine the mixtures. Fry the dal for for 4 to 5 minutes. Turn the heat on to medium-high and cook the dal fry until it thickens and bubbles. This should take 4 to 5 minutes. Stir the dal fry occasionally to keep it from sticking to the pot. Stir in the butter and lemon juice. Turn off the heat and stir in the remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons (21 g) of butter until it melts. Squeeze half of a lemon and stir in the juice until it's incorporated. Serve the dal fry. Sprinkle a little chopped fresh cilantro over the dal fry and serve it while it's thick and hot. Consider serving the dal fry with steamed rice, chapati, naan, or raita. Store the leftover dal fry in an airtight container in the refrigerator. You can keep the dal fry for 2 to 3 days.
